Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diversity, Dominance & Disturbance in Species-Rich Pine Savanna Groundcover
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will test two likely mechanisms for the maintenance of biological diversity in natural habitats, the creation of fine-scale variation in the environment by dominant plant species and by natural disturbance by fire. Some of the most diverse plant communities in North America are found in the fire-prone longleaf pine forest of the southeastern United States. Although the forest canopy generally has only a few species of plants, and the plants beneath are often dominated by one or two species of large, long-lived bunchgrasses, a high number of smaller plant species can be found scattered between the grasses. Researchers will experimentally alter interactions between bunchgrasses, interactions between bunchgrasses and smaller plants, and environmental conditions such as fire intensity to show how dominant plant species influence the diversity and dynamics of high-diversity plant communities in environments prone to disturbance.

Longleaf pine ecosystems historically covered most of the Atlantic and Gulf Coastal Plains, but human activities such as fire suppression have reduced the area of the forests by more than 98%. This project will inform efforts to manage and restore these ecosystems. In particular, a workshop will bring together land managers, conservation professionals, and ecologists to synthesize relevant information about these ecosystems, identify important gaps in our understanding of these floristic treasures, and translate the results into recommendations for conservation, management, and restoration. In addition, the project will train undergraduate and graduate students in science and provide educational outreach activities for K-12 students and educators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High-diversity communities provide rich opportunities for understanding the relative importance of processes underlying community assembly, but have been less-frequently explored experimentally than low-diversity communities. Biodiversity in a high-diversity community typically comprises many relatively rare species and fewer common species. Therefore, interspecific interactions involving common (or dominant) species are likely to engender especially important deterministic mechanisms for community assembly. This is because common species are more likely to interact both with one another and with rare species than rare species are to interact with other rare species.

 

North American longleaf pine savannas in the southeastern United States are among the most biodiverse habitats on Earth. It is not uncommon to find 30 species of flowering plants packed into a small area of groundcover the size of a large kitchen sink. Unfortunately, owing to habitat destruction, relatively little is left of the vast expanses of pine savannas that once covered much of the Southeast. In our project we aimed to better understand the ecological processes that govern these special habitats, both for the sake of basic knowledge and to help manage and restore pine savanna habitat.    

 

For our principal experiment, we removed the physically dominant bunchgrass species (i.e., wiregrass) from groundcover plots at Eglin Air Force Base on the Florida panhandle. We paired those bunchgrass-removal plots with control plots in which the groundcover was left intact. Bunchgrass removal could result in reduced species diversity of remaining species, increased species diversity, or no change, depending on how the dominant species of grass interacts with other species in the groundcover community. To our surprise, there was essentially no change. Although this result suggests that wiregrass has a very limited influence on the groundcover, it may be that our 2.5 year manipulation was too short and that over relatively short term periods the groundcover is fairly resistant to change, whereas with longer-term removal change would occur. In addition, in the context of restoration on agricultural and plantation land, wiregrass may nevertheless have an important diversifying effect as a groundcover community assembles anew.

Compared to wiregrass-removal, habitat had a very strong influence on species composition and biodiversity. As part of her Ph.D. dissertation related to the larger project, a Ph.D. student tested for non-random spatial patterns in the dominant bunchgrasses across sites in the southeastern United States. She measured the size and plotted the location of mature bunchgrass tussocks in three plots in each of six pine savanna sites spanning Louisiana to Florida (18 plots total). She then used sophisticated spatial statistics to assess dispersion patterns of the grass tussocks. She found that the dominant bunchgrasses in these savannas are significantly more regularly patterned than expected by chance, suggesting that intraspecific competition keeps them spaced apart and allows opportunities for small-stature plants to eke out their existence in the interstices among the tussocks. We convened a workshop in association with the 2014 joint Longleaf Alliance and Eastern Native Grass Conference in Mobile, Alabama. The workshop brought together 37 ecologists, land managers, and restoration professionals to discuss the state of the art and science of managing and restoring longleaf ecosystems.
